did.abstract: Howard Spiro was head of the Gastroenterology Unit or Section of the Department of Internal Medicine at Yale from 1955 until his retirement in 1999. He was co-founder and first Director of the Program for Humanities in Medicine. The collection contains typescripts of Spiro's talks and addresses; typescripts of essays, mostly related to issues in humanities in medicine; a manuscript autobiography; correspondence related to Yale; reprints of Spiros's articles, columns, and book reviews; and ten original medical illustrations related to gastroenterology that Spiro had collected.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Boxes 1-5 from the Estate of Howard Spiro, 2012; boxes 6-7 from Howard Spiro, 2008.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Boxes 1-5 papers were in Howard Spiro's office at 40 Temple Street and donated as part of his estate. Boxes 6 and 7 were donated by Howard Spiro in 2008 and added to the collection as a supplement.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Howard M. Spiro, Yale gastroenterologist and medical humanist, was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts on March 23, 1924. He graduated from Harvard College in 1944, majoring in English, and from Harvard Medical School in 1947. After internship, residency, and further study in Boston, interrupted by military service, Spiro came with his wife Marian to New Haven in 1955, recruited by Paul Beeson, chairman of Internal Medicine. He established the first full-time Gastrointestinal Unit at Yale. In 1965 Spiro established the Yale-Affiliated Gastroenterology Program, through which he and his graduate fellows worked with community hospitals in southeastern Connecticut. Spiro was known for his strong dedication to patients and to teaching, and for his research on the relationship between the mind and the gastrointestinal tract. He was sole author of the first three editions of his textbook, Clinical Gastroenterology (1st ed, 1970), and was founder and editor of Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology in 1979. In 1983 Spiro was the co-founder with Enid Peschel and first director of the Program of Humanities in Medicine which featured weekly lectures and conversations. Spiro wrote, edited, or co-edited several books under the aegis of Program, among them Doctors, Patients and Placebos (1986), When Doctors Get Sick (1987), Empathy and the Practice of Medicine(1993), Facing Death (1996), and The Power of Hope (1998). Long interested in the history of medicine and an active member of the Beaumont Medical Club, Spiro and Priscilla Waters Norton published a biography of a former medical dean, Dean Winternitz : Yale Medical School's Passionate Humanist, in 2011. Spiro retired from both his academic position and directorship of the Program in Humanities in Medicine in 1999, but remained associated with the Program until his death in Branford on March 11, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains typescripts of presentations to various audiences; typescripts of essays; correspondence primarily with his residents, but also some on Yale medical politics and from his sabbatical year in London; an incomplete set of reprints, including his medical journal columns on medical humanities for various journals, and his book reviews; reviews of Spiro's books; and photographs of Spiro with colleagues and family. Some folders of essays also include correspondence related to publications, in particular on Spiro's paper on the Nazi-era Pernkopf Atlas and on his biography of Milton Winternitz. There is also material on Spiro's sucessful attempt to end a prize given in West Germany on liver research named after Nazi doctor Hans Eppinger. Most of the talks and essays are on topics in humanities in medicine, and date from the 1960s to 2012. Highlights include speeches in New Haven during the Vietnam War, medical graduation speeches at Yale and elsewhere, and a draft autobiography. The collection also includes ten medical illustrations, some by Yale medical illustrator Armin Hemberger and dating from before Spiro's career, that Spiro collected.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in seven series: 1. Dated typescript lectures and talks. 2. Typescripts and related correspondence by topic. 3. Draft autobiography and miscellaneous. 4. Reprints. 5. Medical illustrations. 6. Supplement: Correspondence and photographs. 7. Supplement: Additional publications and publications about H.M. Spiro.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edouard Pernkopf of Vienna was the author of a Nazi-era anatomical atlas, Topographische Anatomie des Menschen (1937-1960), probably based on preparations made from the bodies of Jewish victims of the Nazi regime. Howard Spiro was invited by Karl Holuber, M.D., Chairman of the Institute of the History of Medicine at the University of Vienna, to participate in a symposium on March 3, 1998. The folder includes Spiro's correspondence and publications by others on the Pernkopf Atlas. There is material on other seminars related to the 50th anniversary of the Nazi doctors trials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes further correspondence, the abstract, and versions the paper that Spiro presented, "The Silence of Words--Some Thoughts on the Pernkopf Atlas." It was published in Wien Klin. Wochenschr. 110 (1998): 183-184. Also in this folder is Universitat Wien, "Information for the Users of the Pernkopf-Atlas," August 1997. Howard Spiro asked that this statement be inserted into the Yale Medical Library's copies of the atlas.

did.unittitle: Reprints of column, "The Optimist" from Scientific American: Science and Medicine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This column by Spiro on topics in humanities in medicine appeared in each of six issues per year starting with May/June 1994. Scientific American: Science and Medicinelater became Science and Medicine. The journal began in 1994, was published erratically toward the end, and terminated in 2005. Columns from 1994 to 2003 were published as Howard M. Spiro, The Optimist: Meditations on Medicine: Collected Essays, 1994-2003 (Narberth, PA: Science and Medicine, 2004).

did.unittitle: Dictaphone transcripts of Howard Spiro, while on sabbatical, to Walter Thayer at Yale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spiro was on sabbatical in 1962-1963 in London, mainly at the Postgraduate Medical School. He communicated with the Section on Gastroenterology by means of dictaphone tapes, a new technology, that enabled a sturdy ring of red tape to be mailed. He corresponded mainly with Walter Thayer who transcribed the tapes. The folder contains the transcripts, a few other letters sent by Spiro, and two examples of the tapes and envelope-mailers.

did.unittitle: Copies of the "Donaldson Report" on the Liver and GI Section

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The "Donaldson Report" was a typescript evaluation, "Report of the Review of the Liver and GI Section," by a committee of three medical professors at Yale, headed by Robert M. Donaldson. The report upset Spiro who felt he was targeted by it. The folder contains copies of the report and Spiro's notes on reading it.

did.unittitle: Spiro's protest against the Eppinger Prize

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spiro discovered that the prestigious Eppinger Prize given for liver research by the Falk Foundation in West Germany was named after a Nazi physician, Hans Eppinger, who experimented on inmates in concentration camps. In response to Spiro's criticism of the award, the organization decided not to award it in the future. Folder contains newspaper articles and a copy of Spiro's editorial "Eppinger of Vienna: Scientist and Villain," Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology 6 (1984): 493-494.
